rev.diff:
Line 43: Line 43:
Linspire's CNR (originally "Click'N'Run") is a software distribution service based on Debian's APT. It is designed to serve as a GUI-based, user-accessible means of downloading and installing various applications, both free and [[proprietary software|proprietary]]. The service allows users to install available applications using a single click. CNR also includes a set of ''Click and Buy'' (CNB) software, which includes many commercial applications to members at a discounted rate. Currently CNR has over 38,000 different software packages, ranging from simple applications to major commercial works such as [[Win4Lin]] and [[OpenOffice.org|StarOffice]].<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.linspire.com/lindows_products_categories.php | title = CNR Warehouse - catalogue of software titles downloadable via CNR | accessdate = 2006-04-27}}</ref> CNR was originally subscription-based with two tiers: ''basic'' service cost $20 annually, and ''gold'', featuring discounts on some commercial applications, $50. In 2006, Linspire announced that the ''basic'' service was to be made available for free.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.linspire.com/lindows_news_pressreleases_archives.php?id=203 | title = Linspire Does Away with Annual Fee for "Click 'N Run" Linux Service | accessdate = 2006-08-30}}</ref>
Linspire's CNR (originally "Click'N'Run") is a software distribution service based on Debian's APT. It is designed to serve as a GUI-based, user-accessible means of downloading and installing various applications, both free and [[proprietary software|proprietary]]. The service allows users to install available applications using a single click. CNR also includes a set of ''Click and Buy'' (CNB) software, which includes many commercial applications to members at a discounted rate. Currently CNR has over 38,000 different software packages, ranging from simple applications to major commercial works such as [[Win4Lin]] and [[OpenOffice.org|StarOffice]].<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.linspire.com/lindows_products_categories.php | title = CNR Warehouse - catalogue of software titles downloadable via CNR | accessdate = 2006-04-27}}</ref> CNR was originally subscription-based with two tiers: ''basic'' service cost $20 annually, and ''gold'', featuring discounts on some commercial applications, $50. In 2006, Linspire announced that the ''basic'' service was to be made available for free.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.linspire.com/lindows_news_pressreleases_archives.php?id=203 | title = Linspire Does Away with Annual Fee for "Click 'N Run" Linux Service | accessdate = 2006-08-30}}</ref>
â
Linspire planned to port CNR to the [[Ubuntu]] distribution, the company announced on [[April 24]] [[2006]] that CNR would be released under an [[open source license|open source licence]]. The release of the free CNR client is planned to coincide with the release of Freespire 2.0 and Linspire 6.0.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://wiki.freespire.org/index.php/Freespire_Roadmap | title=Freespire Roadmap}}</ref> On [[January 23]], [[2007]], Linspire announced that it intended to provide CNR for other [[Linux distributions]], both APT- and [[RPM Package Manager|RPM]]-based, including [[Debian]], [[Fedora (Linux distribution)|Fedora]], [[OpenSUSE]] and [[Ubuntu]]. This support is expected to appear in mid-2007.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.linspire.com/lindows_news_pressreleases_archives.php?id=212 | title=Linspire Standardizes Software Installation Across Linux Distributions}}</ref> On [[February 8]], [[2007]], Linspire, Inc. announced a partnership with [[Canonical Ltd.]], publisher of the Ubuntu Linux distribution. This deal, to take effect before the fourth quarter of 2007, would see Linspire and Freespire migrate from the unpredictable Debian release process to the semiannual Ubuntu release cycle. This means that the main Ubuntu distribution will become the first recipient of the opening of the Click'N'Run service to Linux distributions besides Linspire.<ref>{{cite web|author=Kevin Carmony|url=http://www.linspire.com/linspire_letter_archives.php?id=40|title=Linspire's New Partnership with Canonical and Ubuntu|date=2007-02-08|accessdate=2007-02-08}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Canonical and Linspire Announce Technology Partnership|url=http://www.ubuntu.com/news/LinspirePartnership|title=Canonical and Linspire Announce Technology Partnership|date=2007-02-08|accessdate=2007-02-08}}</ref>
+
Linspire planned to port CNR to the [[Ubuntu]] distribution, the company announced on [[April 24]] [[2006]] that CNR would be released under an [[open source license|open source licence]]. The release of the free CNR client is planned to coincide with the release of Freespire 2.0 and Linspire 6.0.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://wiki.freespire.org/index.php/Freespire_Roadmap | title=Freespire Roadmap}}</ref> On [[January 23]], [[2007]], Linspire announced that it intended to provide CNR for other [[Linux distributions]], both APT- and [[RPM Package Manager|RPM]]-based, including [[Debian]], [[Fedora (operating system)|Fedora]], [[OpenSUSE]] and [[Ubuntu]]. This support is expected to appear in mid-2007.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.linspire.com/lindows_news_pressreleases_archives.php?id=212 | title=Linspire Standardizes Software Installation Across Linux Distributions}}</ref> On [[February 8]], [[2007]], Linspire, Inc. announced a partnership with [[Canonical Ltd.]], publisher of the Ubuntu Linux distribution. This deal, to take effect before the fourth quarter of 2007, would see Linspire and Freespire migrate from the unpredictable Debian release process to the semiannual Ubuntu release cycle. This means that the main Ubuntu distribution will become the first recipient of the opening of the Click'N'Run service to Linux distributions besides Linspire.<ref>{{cite web|author=Kevin Carmony|url=http://www.linspire.com/linspire_letter_archives.php?id=40|title=Linspire's New Partnership with Canonical and Ubuntu|date=2007-02-08|accessdate=2007-02-08}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Canonical and Linspire Announce Technology Partnership|url=http://www.ubuntu.com/news/LinspirePartnership|title=Canonical and Linspire Announce Technology Partnership|date=2007-02-08|accessdate=2007-02-08}}</ref>
=== Web software ===
=== Web software ===
Line 54: Line 54:
[[Image:FreespireScreenshot.png|thumb|Freespire RC1]]
[[Image:FreespireScreenshot.png|thumb|Freespire RC1]]
â
In August 2005, Andrew Betts released a [[Live CD]] based on Linspire and named ''Freespire''.<ref>[http://www.freespire.org Freespire's website.]</ref> Some users mistook this for a product from Linspire, Inc. Linspire, Inc. offered users a "free Linspire" (purchase price discounted to $0) by using the coupon code "Freespire" until [[September 9]] [[2005]]. On [[April 24]] [[2006]], Linspire announced its own project named "Freespire".<ref name=newsforge>{{cite web | url=http://os.newsforge.com/article.pl?sid=06/04/24/1951201 | title=Newsforge: Linspire launches Freespire, open-sources CNR | accessdate=2006-04-25}}</ref> This follows the model of community-oriented releases by [[Red Hat]] and [[Novell]] in the form of [[Fedora (Linux distribution)|Fedora]] and [[openSUSE]]. Freespire is a community-driven and -supported project tied to the commercial Linspire distribution, and includes previously proprietary elements from Linspire, such as the CNR Client, while other elements, which Linspire, Inc. licenses but does not own, like the Windows Media Audio compatibility libraries, remain closed-source. Consequently there are two versions of Freespire, one with the closed source libraries, and one, called Freespire OSS Edition, that includes only open-source components. Freespire 1.0 was released on [[August 7]], [[2006]], three weeks ahead of schedule.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://forum.freespire.org/showthread.php?t=723|title = Freespire version 1.0 is now available}}</ref>
+
In August 2005, Andrew Betts released a [[Live CD]] based on Linspire and named ''Freespire''.<ref>[http://www.freespire.org Freespire's website.]</ref> Some users mistook this for a product from Linspire, Inc. Linspire, Inc. offered users a "free Linspire" (purchase price discounted to $0) by using the coupon code "Freespire" until [[September 9]] [[2005]]. On [[April 24]] [[2006]], Linspire announced its own project named "Freespire".<ref name=newsforge>{{cite web | url=http://os.newsforge.com/article.pl?sid=06/04/24/1951201 | title=Newsforge: Linspire launches Freespire, open-sources CNR | accessdate=2006-04-25}}</ref> This follows the model of community-oriented releases by [[Red Hat]] and [[Novell]] in the form of [[Fedora (operating system)|Fedora]] and [[openSUSE]]. Freespire is a community-driven and -supported project tied to the commercial Linspire distribution, and includes previously proprietary elements from Linspire, such as the CNR Client, while other elements, which Linspire, Inc. licenses but does not own, like the Windows Media Audio compatibility libraries, remain closed-source. Consequently there are two versions of Freespire, one with the closed source libraries, and one, called Freespire OSS Edition, that includes only open-source components. Freespire 1.0 was released on [[August 7]], [[2006]], three weeks ahead of schedule.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://forum.freespire.org/showthread.php?t=723|title = Freespire version 1.0 is now available}}</ref>
